description:
Now tomorrow, American astronaut Scott Kelly is embarking on a very special year-long mission to the International Space Station because Scott's twin brother Mark, who is also an astronaut, will be monitored back on Earth so that the differences between their physiology can be recorded. Mark and Scott are the only twins who have both been in space. They were born and brought up in the state of New Jersey and both had distinguished careers in the US Navy before applying for astronaut training at the American space agency NASA. I spoke to the twins last year.

I think it's very easy to tell us apart but, you know, I never have a problem with it.

What are the signs?

Well, you know, most people use the fact that Mark has a moustache and I do not.

That's a giveaway, isn't it? But when you were younger, Mark, did people use to mistake you for each other?

Yeah, all the time, even at NASA. I had somebody, another astronaut, mistake me for him while he was in space. They would know better.

And Scott, who developed the idea of going into space first?

Now I think he did, 'cause he had applied the time before the time that we both got selected.

Now you both signed up for the Navy and it was from there that you both applied to join NASA. Mark, you led the way. What prompted you to take that decision to apply to NASA?

Yeah, I wanted to serve my country.

It's an exciting career. You know, it's the ultimate. One of the ultimate things to do in aviation is to land and take off after being on an aircraft carrier. But then as a, later as a Navy test pilot, the next logical step for a lot of test pilots is to fly the space shuttle.
